value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">absorbed what the audience can give him; &</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the audience. There is a point when the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">single figure emerges; as if after [absorbing?]</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it was one of the immense advantages of the

            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">age, <del>the entire</del> there was no gap between</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the <del>giver</del> two. <del>It is</del> The <del>author</del>    There is a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">moment when the audience sees itself: given back;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">separate; created, & is no longer the master of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">playwright yet is not separate from him:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a kind of common life <del>still</del> connects them</l>

<del xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <l>It is then that we begin to <del>air the</del></l>
            <l>read: then that we bring into play <del>the</del> all our</l>
            <l><del>whole</del> <del>new</del> resources:  <del>then</del> when the</l>
            <l>figure on the stage is able at last to</l>
            <l><del>g</del> <del>express</del> speak in person: when the words are</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>This is</del> <del>Their</del> This extraordinary intensification</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">comes fitfully: we note a passage that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>seems</del>   it flits through <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-cmar" key="Marlowe, Christopher">Marlowe</rs>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in words like <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-they" key="Heywood, Thomas">Heywoods</rs>: oh God...</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>or in</del> <del>the</del> & of course finally in <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi>.</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>[metal?] is final: we have heat, light,</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>everywhere.</del>     But <del>besides this</del> <del>Beyond</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The reader then extracts out an [hunger?]: for</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">their intensity; for their language.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But beyond this there is also the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">relation of part to part. This <del>hanging</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>comport</del> order, is often attracted. The balance</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is important. The draw of the audience is too</l>
